title: one way stop woke takeover britains elite institutions
story: There was a time when I assumed that the inanities of the age would confine themselves to the dim and third-rate. Sure, the University of Canterbury could treat itself to a lecturer whose expertise was “zombies” and the University of Southampton could employ an “expert” on video games. But this would simply constitute a tax on the gullible and stupid. Eventually applications would fall off, and such institutions would close. The elite institutions, meantime, would purr along like the well-oiled machines that they are. I was wrong.What I failed to take into account was that ancient institutions are expert at adapting to whatever era they are in. And ours is an era whose boundaries have been subtly, but significantly, mis-drawn. Like a post-war border-treaty, a single deviation of the pen stores up trouble generations down the line.In our age anything deemed “hostile” by a member of a “vulnerable group” is made impermissible. Not simply in polite society, but in law – even in policing. What is a “non-crime hate-incident” but a bogus concept written into law? It makes no judgment on whether the “hostility” was real or imagined, and it cannot adjudicate whether the claim is made sincerely or in order to win some other (often political) battle. To make such a claim is to win, leaving our society and its institutions permanently at the mercy of (among others) the deluded and malevolent. Of course institutions that survived the Reformation, the civil war and much more should know how to adapt to the guiding faith of the age. They have spent centuries practising.There has been much attention paid to the case of Will Knowland – the Eton teacher sacked after uploading to YouTube a talk to pupils in which he said that differences between men and women aren’t always attributable to environmental factors.What he said was true. It also runs against one of the prevailing lies of the age (that sex differences are not biological but environmental). So just as in a previous age an Eton master might have made himself vulnerable by doubting the eucharistic bread was the actual body of Christ, so Knowland became vulnerable. But it is the badly drawn laws of this country that did for him.The recognition that such lines must be drawn well is why a fight is going on at another of our ancient institutions. At Cambridge University, a free-speech row is ongoing thanks to its vice chancellor Stephen Toope. This Canadian lawyer heads an institution that has developed an apparent habit of punishing academics who step outside the orthodox lies of the age. Witness Cambridge’s treatment of Noah Carl and Jordan Peterson. Now Toope is trying to double-down by pushing through a new free speech policy. Recognising the drawing of a poorly-drawn line when he sees one, a much smarter man than Toope (senior philosophy lecturer Arif Ahmed) is leading a push-back.The Toope policy demands that differences of opinion be “respected”. Ahmed rightly says that, no, another person cannot simply demand or expect “respect” for their opinion. What we should have is “tolerance” for other people’s opinions.Quite so. The demand of our era that everybody and anything be “respected” has become one of the bully-words to shut down discussion of difficult issues and the bully’s way to bulldoze through their own, often erroneous, claims. Once the line is drawn where Toope wants to draw it, good people (including people telling the truth) are left permanently at risk of being stranded behind enemy lines.This may seem theoretical. But it is not. In defending the sacking of Mr Knowland, the headmaster of Eton said that a lawyer employed to give an opinion on the case warned that Knowland’s speech may have broken this country’s equality laws.And here is the thing. Perhaps it did. But that is because the equality laws of this country – like Toope’s “respect” rule at Cambridge – are an ass. Institutions like Eton hide behind their wretched lawyers only because the law can be interpreted as being on their side. It is no good complaining about cowards in high places if those cowards have (or even believe they have) the law on their side. What would be good would be for this country – and specifically this Conservative Government – to change the law: to undo the last Labour government’s deeply inexact tampering in the Equalities Act.Ancient institutions are designed to adapt to survive whatever era they are in. It is no surprise that they have adapted to our new woke state religion. For as long as they have the law on their side, it is not enough to demand the presence of braver or better people at the top of our institutions. It is necessary to change those laws. And the religion.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: rewilding wild swimming nature has hijacked modern day marie
story: In the decade I defined recently in this column as the Troubled Teens, many words have changed their meaning. Now, it isn’t just old fogeys muttering darkly about verbal appropriation, as one lovely word after another falls to the monstrous regiments of the woke. I am, too.“Brave” – once meant rescuing orphans from burning buildings now means talking about one’s troubles in public. “Activist” – once meant getting out and about to help others now means staying indoors on the internet screaming at people who think differently. “Community” – once meant a cheery group of neighbours getting together for street parties now means a posse of peevish wallflowers going for gold in the Victimhood Olympics.And now “wild” – a word which, predictably, I have a weakness for. The Cambridge Dictionary defines it as “uncontrolled or extreme” with the slang “unusual, often in a way that is attractive or exciting”. This is the wildness that produced numerous cultural artefacts: songs like Wild Thing, films like Wild At Heart, books like Where The Wild Things Are.But in recent years there’s been a creeping encroachment of a version of the word which doesn’t mean life-affirming risk but rather self-denying caution – to quote Cambridge, “wild land is not used to grow crops and has few people living on it”. “Rewilding” predictably showed up in the woke Archers a while back when the rich old Archer matriarch Peggy awarded half a million pounds to a “rewilding” project. Though it seemed an unlikely alliance at first, it’s worth remembering that “conservative” and “conservation” have a common root – and probably a manky old root thieved from common land and made into a stew, if the two-legged hedge-hogs have anything to do with it.Lockdown, meanwhile, has exacerbated the craze for foraging as part and parcel of the wildness trend, along with wild swimming (swimming outside) and wild dining (dining outside) to the point where Epping Forest – once most notorious for dogging – has been rebooted as an Essex Eden, keen to share its opulent bounty with the furloughed.You can see how plague-laden supermarkets might make outdoor scavenging look like the healthy way to get your five a day, but I’m not convinced. As a big people fan, I’ve never been overkeen on nature when as a teenager I heard that there was a book called Against Nature, I became so thrilled I carried a copy around for a year, as though it was a trendy Etam handbag. This aversion stayed with me into adulthood, to the somewhat illogical point where, living in a house with fruit trees in the garden, I would leave them for the birds and buy apples from the supermarket, all nicely done up in plastic.In recent years, commercial mushroom foragers in Epping Forest have been fined thousands of pounds for removing the fungi that supports ancient trees and serves as food for wildlife such as deer. I’ve never trusted mushrooms since I saw some growing on the bathroom carpet of a friend (reader, I married him!) and the idea of breaking the law in order to get your greedy paws on some does strike me as somewhat surreal. And the only forager I ever knew fell in a stagnant pond while reaching for blackberries, having scratched her arms and legs soon after, she woke up with a brain infection and had to learn to walk all over again. Give me the concrete fields of the city any day, where you can see trouble coming.As a counter-jumping meritocrat, I’ve always thought Nature best left to the posh like them it doesn’t have a lot to say and clings blindly to an outdated “natural” order. Scratch a friend of the earth and find an enemy of earthlings look how ecology movements are so white and bourgeois they make a Monday Club meeting look like the Reggae Sunsplash festival. Because rewilding is an attempt to go back in time, before pesky people and their petty desires to have a decent standard of living caused human habitats to blight the landscape.“Gonna make it happenTake the world in a love embrace” sang Steppenwolf in one of my favourite songs Born To Be Wild. Let the modern Marie Antoinettes keep their fellow humans six feet away while they gorge themselves on buckshee fungi this fashion for “the wild” is an adventure only for the mild at heart.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: rita ora apologises second covid rules breach
story: Rita Ora has been forced to apologise again after it emerged she had broken strict coronavirus rules by failing to self-isolate after recently travelling to Egypt.The 30-year-old singer reportedly travelled to Cairo on November 21 to perform at the five-star W hotel. She returned the next day and under Government quarantine rules should have self-isolated for 14 days, the Mail on Sunday reported.But less than a week later she held a birthday party at a restaurant in west London.Ms Ora was forced to apologise last week after she and around 30 guests, including model Cara Delevingne, were photographed at the event before the end of the second national lockdown on Wednesday.The singer had offered to pay a £10,000 fine for hosting the party.Ms Ora told the Mail on Sunday she would donate any profit from the performance to charity. In a statement, she told the newspaper: “I recently flew to Egypt to perform at a corporate event for a private company, where my travel party followed protocol and presented negative Covid tests upon entry, as required by Egyptian authorities. Upon my return to Britain, I should have followed Government advice and isolated myself for the required period. As you know, I didn’t follow Government advice and… I apologise again, unreservedly.“While I realise the apologetic words of a pop star might not carry much weight, especially one who has broken the rules like I have, I do realise some might seek to follow my example. My message to them is simple: please don’t. The guilt and shame I’ve carried this week for my mistake aren’t worth it. Instead, continue to listen to the Government advice and the voices of the heroes of the NHS and take the required precautions.”A spokesman for the star said she and her team had all subsequently tested negative for coronavirus. Ms Ora’s agent has been approached for comment.Premier League footballers Jack Grealish and Ross Barkley were also filmed this weekend celebrating Mr Barkley's birthday at a London restaurant, The Sun reported.In an alleged breach of the restrictions, which ban people from socialising with anyone who doesn’t live in their household unless they are part of a support bubble, the two Aston Villa players were filmed in a crowded restaurant and witnesses said they saw the group drinking champagne, vodka and beer.An Aston Villa spokesman told The Sun: Having reviewed footage forwarded to us on Saturday, it appears as though two of our players who live in tier 2 areas of the country were eating in a restaurant in a tier 2 location on Saturday afternoon during a weekend off. They left the restaurant at 7.45pm.Agents for Mr Grealish and Mr Barkley have been approached for comment.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: covid 19 vaccine safe questions
story: AdvertorialIs it safe  Experts answer your biggest questions about the Covid- vaccineFrom side effects to safety, we ask the medical experts everything you want to know about the new Pfizer BioNTech Covid- vaccinemirrorShareByDave Masters:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC AdvertorialFollowing months of rigorous clinical trials, the Pfizer BioNTech Covid- vaccine has been approved for use in the UK by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency. This and the other vaccines are a huge step forward in the fight against coronavirus and could save tens of thousands of lives. So is the vaccine safe  Who’ll get it first  And will it mean ato normal le  Our  of medical experts - made up of Deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, Chief Executive of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency Dr June Raine CBE and Head of Immunisations at Public Health England Dr Mary Ramsay - are here to answer all your questions...  Q. Vaccines usually take years to develop, so how can the Covid- vaccination be safeit’s ready in months  Professor Van-Tam: These vaccines have been through phase one, phase two and phase three, just like ordinary vaccines. With the Pfizer vaccine, I think the total clinical trial size is something like , the AstraZeneca results so far reported are based on just over , volunteers – there’s at least another , to follow, and the number size for Moderna is very similar. These are very, very big studies. The numbers involved were essentially the same as you’d expect for a normal peacetime vaccine, and on top of that the safety assessments and the assessments of effectiveness at the end are the same. Dr Raine: The public can be completely confident that Covid- vaccines will only be available once they have met robust standards of safety, quality and effectiveness. As Covid- is a public health emergency, scientic evaluation and approval is being done in the shortest time possible while complying with established and robust safety, quality and effectiveness standards. Extensive knowledge on vaccine development with existing vaccines is applied. Safety is our watchword. Everyone can be absolutely clear that the standards that need to be met, will be met. I am completely confident that there has been no pressure whatsoever on the agency and our expert staff to pass the vaccine. None at all. Q. How have you decided who gets the vaccine first  Dr Ramsay: We looked at a lot of data showing who was getting infection and who was dying from infection. The primary thing the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationlooked at was death rates by age, by clinical factors, and by any other factors that GPs could measure, such as deprivation, geography or ethnicity. It’s very clear the death rate is much higher as you get older, particularly over . That’s why we’re prioritising people in older age groups, then coming down in age, picking up people who are clinically vulnerable and those who have underlying conditions along the way. Those working in health and social care will be high on the list as well – they are at risk because they’re getting exposed to infection every day and they may be spreading it to others. The same goes for care home workers – they’re a very high priority.  Q. Will the vaccine prevent disease or just reduce symptoms   Professor Van-Tam: If you’re going to prevent transmission you need a vaccine that is taking out the illness and also the asymptomatic infections. There are some signs from AstraZeneca that this might be the case. That does not mean the other vaccines where results have already been announced or that are or are still in development, don’t also reduce transmission it’s just we don’t know at this point in time. We hope they will because they’ll have a bigger effectthey can take out transmission. Q. Are there any side effects  Dr Ramsay: All the side effects are predictable – the kind of thing you get with other vaccines: a sore arm, bit of a temperature or feeling a bit fatigued, so we’re expecting it to have a similar safety profile to other vaccines. Professor Van-Tam: Every single vaccine authorised for use in the UK has been authorised by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency . The three components of authorisation are a safety assessment, an effectiveness assessment and a manufacturing quality assessment – all three need to be ticked before anything is authorised. But there is not a single medicine without side effects. Is it possible that rare side effects could come to light that you’d never pick up in a clinical trial of ,-, patients  Yes, it is – but that’s no dferent from any other medicine.  Q. How will the vaccine be rolled out  Dr Ramsay: The actual act of giving the injection isn’t particularly skillful – all nurses are trained and most vaccines are given by nurses, but with the flu jab we use health care assistants. The key thing is they work under the supervision of nurses. I think there’s going to be a lot of dferent models used because, for example, with elderly, frail people they’re clearly not going to drive to the nearest centre – you might have to take vaccine to them in their home. The hospitals will probably be doing their staff, then there will potentially be these vaccination sites which will probably be more important for the slightly younger population who can drive there. Q. Is there anyone who shouldn’t have it   Dr Ramsay: A reason to defer a vaccination is being pregnant – that’s just being precautionary. We don’t expect there to be a problem, but without having the vaccine tested on pregnant women we’ll probably recommend they wait until after they’ve had the baby. Similarly, it hasn’t been tested in children, although a teenager would probably respond similarly to a young adult so they could likely have the vaccine. Q. Will it be available privately  Professor Van-Tam: I don’t know, but I think it would be a bad thing for public healththe rich and privileged were able to pay their way to the front of the queue, leaving someone at very high risk and not wealthy low down the list – and they would be there’s going to be a global shortage of these vaccines. So I’m opposed to that. Q. How long will it take to immunise as many people as is needed for us toto normal le

title: dont brexit deal three sticking
story: NewsWhy dont we have a Brexit deal  The three sticking points explainedFishing, governance and the level playing field are standing in the way of a trade deal between the EU and UK - and mean Boris Johnson could confirm a no-deal within daysits not resolved. Here are the issues, explainedmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsBoris Johnson promised an oven-ready Brexit deal - so how is he getting on  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Britain still has no trade deal with the EU - less than a month before Brexit properly starts on January .Boris Johnson has sent his chief negotiator Lord Frost to Brussels for  hours of talks in a “last roll of the dice”.If we donapost make enough progress by Monday night on three key issues - fish, EU rules and governance - a UK source warned it could be curtains for a trade deal. That could mean we crash out of EU rules without a trade pact - with tarfs and paperwork being slapped on much of the UK’s £bn a year in trade with the EU from January . Food could become more expensive in the supermarket and deliveries could be held up by bureaucracy at the border.  The Budget watchdog says it could cut GDP by % in  and delay our Covid recovery by almost a year. It’s a far cry from when Boris Johnson said in : “There is no plan for no deal because we are going to get a great deal.” And it’s hardly the “oven-ready” deal the Prime Minister promised the British people he had in last year’s election. So what are the three sticking points  Why hasn’t the so-called “oven-ready deal” been as tasty as we hoped  And when might the deadlock end  Here’s what you need to know.What is the deal we’re trying to agree  The UK is trying to agree a Free Trade Agreement with the EU for when the Brexit transition period ends on December . This would allow us to enjoy cheaper, easier trade with our nearest neighbours thanwe crashed out of the EU with no pact. While no deal will be as seamless as EU membership, Brexiteers say an FTA is a way of having our cake and eating it. We could make our own laws while also paying smaller tarfs and having less bureaucracy than a nation with no trade deal.  If we don’t get a deal, EU trading rules will end on New Year’s Eve and slap billions in tarfs overnight on essential goods. Britain is also negotiating trade deals with dozens of other countries like Japan but the EU is far, far more important. In  the EU accounted for almost half of UK trade - £bn. The second-placed US counted for £bn. Japan, £bn. And our economy has been used to tarf-free EU trade for decades, meaning any change on January  could be a big shock. How is this dferent from Boris Johnson’s ‘oven-ready deal’   You may remember Boris Johnson won the election by promising to ‘get Brexit done’. He said: “We’ve got a deal that’s oven-ready. We’ve just got to put it in at gas mark four, give it  minutes and Bob’s your uncle.” But his “oven-ready” deal was only the Withdrawal Agreement to leave the EU.That agreement didn’t actually guarantee how anytradewould work after .Call it clever wording, call it lies - however you look at it, the ‘oven-ready’ deal doesn’t help us much now. It’s like he put an empty pie casing in the oven to blind-bake, but hadn’t mixed any of the filling together yet. Why don’t we have an agreement yet   The EU and UK have been negotiating an agreement since Spring, but since about the summer talks have been deadlocked. They are stuck on three issues - fishing rights, the ‘level playing field’ and how any deal will be policed . Talks missed deadlines of mid-October and mid-November, before coming to what the UK claimed was almost a breakthrough. But the EU then “added a whole load of additional demands”, according to Environment Secretary George Eustice. UK officials believe French President Emmanuel Macron was behind the new harder position. Adding to this, there’s a row over Boris Johnson planning to break international law. The UK Internal Market Bill - due in the Commons on Monday - will give the UK ultimate power over the rules for goods travelling from Great Britain to Northern Ireland. This would breach the Withdrawal Agreementwhich the UK and EU signed last year. Back then, Boris Johnson promised to arbitrate those rules via a joint committee. When will the logjam end   Boris Johnson and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen are due to speak on Monday evening. Talks might continue beyond that point - andthey do, UK officials believe it will be a good sign. Thataposs becauseprogress is made thereaposll be no point giving up on it on Monday night. Butthere isnapost any progress by Monday night it could be curtains at that point, a UK source warned. Any deal ideally wants to be agreed by EU leaders at a summit this week before being signed off by the European Parliament before New Year. The three sticking points explainedFishing The UK and EU each want as much fish as possible from UK waters after December . But it’s not as simple as just barring all EU fishermen. There needs to be a negotiation - otherwise UK fleets would struggle to access EU waters, or sell their fish into EU markets. The first key point is quotas - whether UK boats will be allowed to catch more fish in their own waters than they do now. In -, % of the fish in UK waters was caught by EU boats and % by UK boats. Reports suggested the EU was prepared to% of its current quotas to UK fishermen, but Britain said this wasn’t enough. Before talks stalled last week, a deal taking back as much as % of EU quotas to the UK seemed possible, it is claimed. Environment Secretary George Eustice said: “The EU have suggested a very modest increase that they would tolerate the UK having of the fish in its own waters. But given we only have half the fish in our own waters now, that simply wouldn’t be possible.” Quotas cover many issues but not all of them - because fish move around the seas. The other key point is over access - both to the territorial waters within  miles of UK soil, and a -mile economic exclusion zone around its coastline. UK sources say the EU essentially wants the same access as it enjoys now under the Common Fisheries Policy. That is unacceptable to UK officials, who say they want to control access to UK waters - even , in reality, EU fleets will be let in anyway. Mr Eustice said the EU was trying to get access to UK waters “in perpetuity” rather than agreeing three years at a time. “Such a suggestion really is quite ludicrous and not consistent with international law,” he said. Itaposs thought the UK is looking at a three-year transition period to new access arrangements.The level playing field

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe first doses of the coronavirus vaccine have arrived in hospitals in England. Hundreds of thousands of doses arrived in the UK on Friday on refrigerated trucks from Belgium. From there they were taken to specialist refrigerated storage facilities, at undisclosed locations, before finally being shipped to the  hospitals taking part in stage one of the rollout. And the first pictures of vaccine arriving in an NHS hospital, released today, show a pharmacy technician from Croydon Health Services taking delivery at Croydon University Hospital of the first batch to be delivered to the area. The UK has secured  million doses of the vaccine, enough to treat  million people in the coming months. The doses will be administered at dozens of hospital hubs from Tuesday – with people aged  and over, care home workers and NHS workers who are at higher risk the first to receive the jab. There are  hubs in the first wave of the vaccination programme in England, with more hospitals starting to vaccinate over the coming weeks and months as the programme ramps up. The distribution of the vaccine across the UK is being undertaken by Public Health England and the NHS in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland through systems specially adapted from those used for the national immunisation programmes.  It comes as Matt Hancock claimed that a second vaccine, made by Oxford University and AstraZeneca may be approved for use in the UK as soon as Christmas. The Health Secretary suggested that the UK made jab could quickly follow the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine, and become the second to get the green light from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency . He said “It may come before Christmas, it may come early in the new year. On Sunday the UKaposs chief medicine regulator said there was no doubt that the Covid vaccine approved in the UK is safe.  Mr Hancock also claimed a successful rollout would mean lockdown restrictions could end before March. The Health Secretaryaposs optimistic prediction comes as hospitals are preparing to begin the first phase of the largest-scale vaccination campaign in the UKaposs history. GP surgeries in England have been told to start staffing COVID- vaccination centres by  December. Dr June Raine, chief executive of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency , which approved the Pfizer BioNTech jab, said there “should be no doubt whatever that this is a very safe and highly effective vaccine”.  Asked on the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show about how important the public health message is to make sure that people actually take the vaccine, she said: “It’s vitally important. And I would really like to emphasise that the highest standards of scrutiny, of safety and of effectiveness and quality have been met, international standards. And so there should be real confidence in the rigour of our approval. The deputy chief executive of NHS Providers said the UK is expecting to receive up to four million doses of the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine by the end of December. But Saffron Cordery explained the dficulty of getting the virus into care homes and smaller community-based vaccination centres. She told Sky Newsaposs Sophy Ridge On Sunday that only hospitals had the infrastructure to store the vaccines because of the incredibly low temperature it is required to be stored at.  She said hospitals receiving the first batch of vaccines were calling people aged  and over in their areas to come into hospitals and setting up separate clinics on-site. Right now they can only be administered in hospitals but trusts up and down the country are working with the MHRA , who is overseeing this process, to seethey can get them distributed more closely to care homes so that they can go into care homes and sort the vaccines for those residents, she said. Professor Stephen Powis, NHS national medical director, said: Despite the huge complexities, hospitals will kickstart the first phase of the largest scale vaccination campaign in our countryaposs history from Tuesday.  Ben Osborn, the UK chief executive of Pfizer, told The Mail on Sunday that he is so confident about the safety of the jab that he is willing to take it today and wants his mother to have it as soon as possible.Mr Hancock has reportedly been referring to Tuesday as V-Day and told The Sundaythat he canapost wait to scrap the three-tier system of coronavirus restrictions before March and get back to living by mutual respect and personal responsibility, not laws set in parliament.When askedthe distribution of the vaccine beginning this week could mean restrictions end sooner, he said: Yes, it will. He added: Thereaposs no doubt that having the vaccine early... will bring forward the moment when we can get rid of these blasted restrictions but until then we have got to follow them. It came as plans emerged to see millions of doses of the Covid- vaccine manufactured in Belgium flown into this country by military aircraft to avoid delays at ports caused by Brexit, under contingency plans being developed by the government.Both the Department of Health and Social Care, and senior sources at the Ministry of Defence , confirmed that large consignments would be brought to the UK from  January by airroad, rail and sea routes were subject to widely expected delays after that date. On the threat of no-deal Brexit Dr Raine said we are ready”. “We’ve practised, we are ready, we are fully prepared for any possible outcome,” she told Andrew Marr. Elsewhere, the Queen and Prince Philip are both expected to have the coronavirus vaccine within weeks but palace sources insisted they “will not jump the queue” and instead have it at the appropriate time. The monarch,  and Duke of Edinburgh, , will both be eligible in the second round of vaccinations aftercare home residents.  Palace sources suggested the royal would be reluctant to go public with their decision to be vaccinated, despite figures in government feeling it would send a strong message to the public. Meanwhile, there is still no guaranteed date for when care home residents will be vaccinated despite them being at the top of the priority list, with Health Secretary Matt Hancock saying there are “signicant challenges” to overcome.  Logistical issues mean there are dficulties in getting the jab to residents, as the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine needs to be stored at minus C before being thawed out and can only be moved four times within that cold chain before being used. The vaccine boxes containing  doses will need to be split so that they can be brought to care homes. Dr Raine told Marr: “We have approved how the vaccine can be put into the small packs, but obviously what we’re doing is giving advice and guidance on how well that, carefully, that is done.

Figures from Britainaposs biggest foodbank network, the Trussell Trust, suggest it could hand out nearly two-and-a-half million meals in the first three weeks of December. Two fths are set to go to kids. Statistics seen by the Mirror show the charity gave away , parcels in the first three weeks of December . With each aid package containing enough ingredients for three meals a day for three meals, that equates to ,, meals.  Of the , parcels provided, , went to children – food for , meals.However, the charity is braced for record demand this festive season as the country battles the coronavirus pandemic and unemployment climbs.In the six months from April to September this year, demand for Trussell Trust help rocketed by % as the UK was gripped by the worst of the Covid- crisis. If the % year-on-year rise continues this month, the charity will provide , parcels to children between December  and  – the equivalent of ,, meals.  They would be among a total of , parcels containing enough food for ,, meals. Trussell Trust chief executive Emma Revie said: “This year communities across the country have stepped in to provide vital support to people left without enough money. “Volunteers in foodbanks have been working tirelessly under extremely dficult circumstances to make sure support is there for people struggling to afford essentials.  “Our volunteers are now bracing themselves for an extremely busy Christmas period - but it’s not right that any of us are forced to a charity for food, at any time of year.” Child Poverty Action Group chief executive Alison Garnham said: “It would sink any parent’s heart to have to go to a foodbank to feed their kids. “But as these figures show, for so many families now it’s aposeat from the foodbank or don’t eat at allapos that isn’t right.  “The pandemic has exposed just how many families are on precarious incomes, and it’s revealed that the safety net we have just isn’t adequate when times are tough.”She called for the Government to extend a temporary £-a-week rise in Universal Credit, which was a announced in March and is due to end in April.“That would be a big help to the millions of families struggling to stay afloat,” she added. Labour and the Liberal Democrats echoed the call.Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said: “Too many families are facing real stress about how they will get by this December.  “Our social security system is not fit for purpose when so many people need to turn to foodbanks to afford essentials this Christmas. “The Government must do more to support people and scrap its planned cut to Universal Credit, which will take £ a week from six million families.” Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey said: “Too many people had to rely on foodbanks even before the pandemic, but the jump in demand since April makes horribly clear the scale of the hardship caused by coronavirus.

title: new plan take pets holiday
story: NewsNew plan to take pets on holiday after Brexit - but itll still be harder than it is nowPet owners may be told to visit the vet one month before taking a dog, cat or ferret abroad, rather than four months as many fear. But its still more of a burden than we enjoy nowmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC NewsMany pet owners are unaware therell be more paperwork when going abroad after Brexit " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTaking pets on holiday after Brexit may become slightly easier than feared under a plan set to be unveiled within days. UK ministers are expecting to be able to announce a halfway-house deal on pet travel to the continent from January. Under the proposed scheme, Brits would need to visit the vet around a month before taking a dog, cat or ferret to the EU. That would be a big drop from a four-month process which was expected to take force from January .However, it’s still much more of a burden than the current pet passport scheme, which is ending in Britain due to Brexit.The compromise was hinted at today by Environment Secretary George Eustice. He told the BBC: “We’re likely to be listed in the EU’s Annex II, the second category. “[That] means whereas in the past you might have had a pet passport, in future you’d need a certicate from the vet instead of a passport. “It won’t be as easy as having the passport because you’d need to go to the vet prior to leaving, rather than have the passport that shows your rabies vaccines are up to date.” A Whitehall source said they were expecting a formal announcement in the coming days.  Until now, the UK government has been working on the basis that Britain will be an “unlisted” nation for pet travel. That would mean any pet owner taking a dog, cat or ferret to the EU from January  must go through a four-month process, including waiting three months after a blood sample. Mr Eustice, however, said it is “likely” the EU will agree for the UK to become a “listed” nation. It is understood he was referring to a process called ‘Part ’ listing, which applies to most listed nations outside the EU. Under this category, the rules for British pet owners would be less stringent than for an unlisted country.

title: vaccine regulator chief urges people
story: NewsVaccine regulator chief urges people to get jab eventhey’ve had coronavirus before June Raine, chief executive of the MHRA regulator, said people should be confident about having the jab - eventhey were previously sick and might have immunitymirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC NewsThe first doses of the UKs first approved vaccine will begin rollout on Tuesday " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPeople should be “completely confident” about having the coronavirus vaccine eventhey’ve previously been infected, a medical chief has said. June Raine, chief executive of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency , urged everyone who is eligible to get the jab when it becomes available to their group. “Itaposs as safe as any general vaccine, the kind you might haveyouaposre going on holiday, or the flu jab,” she told the BBC. Pregnant women and some immunocompromised people are being advised not to take the only approved jab so far, from Pfizer, because there is not yet full data about how it could affect them. But Dr Raine, who leads the regulator which approved the Pfizer jab, confirmed there are “no special precautions or advice” for people who’ve already had Covid-. That means,people who were previously sick are offered the jab, they should take it just as anyone . That is despite the fact they might have some immunity already. Evidence from government SAGE advisors, published on Friday, suggested a “high proportion” of people have some immunity after catching Covid- and it is “likely to persist for at least three months”. But it is uncertain how long this “natural” immunity lasts, and some people do not develop immunity at all. It is also possible that previous sufferers could still transmit Covid when they’re re-infected, eventhey don’t get sick.  The advice also comes despite the fact some people who were previously ill have crippling ‘Long Covid’ symptoms. Askedher general advice to take the vaccine still applied to people with ‘Long Covid’, Dr Raine said: “No special advice there either. “I think people can be really sure this has been looked at in a large number of people, ,, and looked at incredibly carefully. “Of course we want to follow up more in the long term - we have good data up to one month after the second dose, but we’ll be following up safety for at least two years. “So please be confident that as soon as we have more data, we will be sharing it.”  The first COVID- vaccines will arrive at hospitals by Monday ahead of the first jabs being given on Tuesday. GP surgeries in England have been told to start staffing COVID- vaccination centres by  December.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has reportedly been referring to Tuesday as V-Day and told The Sundaythat he canapost wait to scrap the three-tier system of coronavirus restrictions before March.

title: voice people elderly deserve respect
story: NewsopinionVoice of the People: Our elderly deserve respect after , lost to Covid-Callous decisions by the Government during the pandemic have seen the elderly treated poorly, and there are concerns their leline might be coming as soon as hopedmirrorShareCommentsByVoice of the People:,  DEC NewsopinionOur old people deserve to be front of the line for coronavirus vaccine" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIs there no end to the indignity endured by our loved ones in care homes  They suffered – and up to , tragically died – during the pandemic because of scandalously callous decisions made by Health Secretary Matt Hancock and ministers. Now they are being treated unfairly when it comes to getting the Covid vaccine. The Government – through experts on the Joint Committee for Vaccination and Immunisation – says they should be first in the queue because they are the most vulnerable. Of course they should. But it turns out those most vulnerable of all are likely to be at the back of the queue. Technical problems with the Pfizer jab mean it won’t be able to be taken into residential homes. That means only those who are mobile will have the dubious privilege of being loaded onto buses to be transported to hospitals and vaccination hubs. It may be a day out for them. But for the bedridden, ailing and those suffering mental illness it will mean staying behind, left wondering about their fate. And, perhaps despairingly, wondering: why  The technical problem was known about weeks ago.

title: what happens after brexit everything
story: NewsWhat happens after Brexit  How things changewe get a deal - andwe dontEvenwe do get a deal, things are going to look very dferent for Britain from  January . From passports and EU nationals to holidays, pets and data roaming, here are the biggest things that will changemirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC News " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The UK and EU are locked in talks over a Brexit trade deal - and time is running out.If we donapost get a deal, there will be serious knock-on effects to the economy and Britainaposs ports - which could hit food prices, car plants, medicines and more. But evenwe do get a deal, things are going to look very dferent for Brits who go abroad from  January . When Brexit happened on January , we entered an -month transition period where EU rules continued as they are now. That means you’ve been able to go on holiday with pets, passports and free roaming and healthcare, asnothing had changed, and businesses can trade freely with the EU.At the stroke of pm on December , many of these protections will fall away. Some of the effects may be less severethe UK and EU agree a trade deal, but others will come into force regardless. So how will Brexit affect your day-to-day le and holidays after January  and what should you do to prepare  Here’s a basic guide. If we donapost get a trade deal with the EU If we get a trade deal with the EU, it will make importing and exporting goods easier and cheaper than it would otherwise be, with less paperwork and fewer tarfs. Itaposll be more similar to how things are now . Butwe donapost, there will be billions of pounds a year in extra costs for businesses. That is because we will default to more expensive World Trade Organisation trading terms. That could mean disruption at ports and passing on costs to consumers, with everyday goods getting more expensive in the supermarket. This will be more noticeable with the EU than other countries we donapost have a trade deal with, because the EU makes up almost half our trade. Food prices could go up  Tory George Eustice admitted that the UK crashing out could push food prices up. Askedfood prices would risethere’s no trade deal, the Environment Secretary told LBC Radio: “Yes we’ve looked at that. The impact of tarfs on consumer food prices is actually quite modest. Probably less than %.” In the event of no-deal tarfs averaging  per cent will be imposed on food and drink imported from the continent, with retailers likely to pass somenot all of this additional cost onto consumers. The UK imports around  per cent of its food, with  per cent coming from the EU, leaving UK’s supermarket shelves particularly exposed to any disruption on our relationship with the continent. Disruptions at the border could also cause delays in importing food into the country - potentially leading to shortages of certain imported favourites. Medicine could be disrupted  Experts have warned that failing to strike a post-Brexit trade agreement could disrupt the flow of some medicine into the UK. In September, trade bodies the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industryand European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associationsurged both sides to prioritise medicines in trade talks “to protect the supply of medicines for  million patients and safeguard the signicant opportunities that working together on medicines research and development brings to both economies”. The Government has also been working on contingency plans including creating buffer stocks of certain medical suppliers where possible and tendering for a £m freight contract to act as a back up to ensure that Category  goods, which would include vaccines, will be able to be imported to the UK. But with complex supply chains that stretch across the continent pharmacists and doctors are concerned about the consequences of no deal. Officials have been keen to stress that it will not disrupt the vaccine arriving in the UK - with officials having wargamed disruption and ministers ready to order to military flights to make sure that doses of the vaccine can arrive without interruptions. Cars become more expensive The UKaposs car industry risks losing £bn in manufacturing value within five years in the event of a no-deal Brexit, according to an industry analysis. British car production could drop below m cars a yearthere is no deal, compared with more than .m in , because tarfs would make large parts of the UK business unviable, said forecasts commissioned by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, the industry lobby group. No deal would result in % tarfs being applied overnight, adding £, to the average cost of a car imported from the EU. And a no-deal Brexit would jeopardise the future of UK plants. PSA Group has said it will only build its new Vauxhall Astra in the UKthere is a trade deal, while Nissan has said the business model of its Sunderland plant – the largest car factory in the UK – would be destroyed. Chaos at the borders  A No-Deal would likely create chaos at Britain’s borders with delays in getting goods into and out of Europe. Areas around Britain’s largest ports have spent months preparing but local authorities are still fearful of huge backlogs choking motorways in Kent. Companies exporting goods with also face tarfs on WTO terms and the added uncertainty of how to transport their goods to the EU. The licences that hauliers need for work in Europe would no longer be valid and they would be reliant on a limited number of permits from the European Conference of Ministers of Transport Even in the event of a deal government has quietly confirmed a list of  lorry parks to deal with the fallout from Brexit. The ‘inland sites’ will be built in Kent, Essex, Birmingham, Warrington and North Wales - with seven of them due to being ready by January. Violence in Northern Ireland  Spooks have warned that the UK failing to secure a deal could lead to increased violence in Northern Ireland. A report by Parliament’s intelligence and security committeewarned that changes on the island of Ireland could reignite dissident republican violence. MI devoted % of its resources to countering terrorism in Northern Ireland in the year to March . The failure would also create more immediate problems Without a trade deal, the ide between Britain and Northern Ireland would become more distinct. Brexit without a trade deal could allow Northern Ireland to become a back door into the EU’s single market, thus raising the spectre of a hard border on the island of Ireland for the first time since a  peace deal. The  Good Friday Agreement brought an end to three decades of sectarian violence between mainly Protestant Unionists who favour continued British rule and mainly Catholic Irish Nationalists who want a united Ireland. A big hit to the economy - and delayed Covid recovery The Office for Budget Responsibility said the failure to reach a free trade agreement with the EU will “compound” the massive impact of Covid and delay economic recovery by a year.  caused the biggest fall in economic output in  years with % of GDP being wiped out. But a failure to reach an agreement and defaulting to World Trade Organisation trms, including tarfs on trade with the EU, would cause even more damaging to the UKaposs faltering economy. This would “have the effect of delaying the point at which output regains its pre-virus peak by almost a year to the third quarter of ”. If you run a businessIn practical terms,you donapost run a business you might not see a direct impact on your family straight away. For business owners,we donapost a deal, the UK Global Tarf will apply to goods you import from the EU from  January .It applies to imports from all countries, unless you are importing from a country that the UK has a trade deal with, a country that is part of the Generalised Scheme of Preferences or where an exception applies.Use the tarf lookup tool to check the tarfs that may apply to goods you import from  January .Most traders with a good compliance record will be able to defer declarations on most goods for up to six months after  January .You can get more information here.Whether we get an EU trade deal or notWhatI run a business Whether thereaposs a trade deal or not, business owners will sill need to make customs declarations when they import goods from the EU. Thataposs because weaposre leaving the EU customs union and single market, evenwe get a trade deal. Most businesses get someone to deal with customs for them.Customs agents, freight forwarders and express operators can help you with declarations and ensure you are providing the necessary information. Click here to find out more.Businesses will need to check what new licences and certicates they may now need. Firms also need to check the rules for importing alcohol, tobacco and certain oils. You need an EORI number to import goods from  January . You will need this to complete customs declarations.The number is needed to use HMRC’s customs systems, soyou don’t get one before the end of the transition period your goods may be delayed, and you risk having to pay storage fees for your goods. Click here to get one. Should I renew my passport  You do not automatically need a new passport because of Brexit. Your old one remains valid evenit says ‘European Union’ on the cover. However, you must renew your passportit has less than six months before expiry on the day you travel. At the moment, British citizens can enter aposSchengen areaapos countries with a valid passport eventhey only have a day left. This changes from  January . After this date, your passport must have at least six months left. Your passport must also be no more than  years old, evenit has six months left before expiry. The following are members of the Schengen Agreement: Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland. Do I need a visa Tourists will not need a visa for short trips to EU countries, of up to  days. This exemption also includes Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland. However, you will most like need a visayou are going to the EU to live, work or study.WhatI have a pet  EU ‘pet passports’ for dogs, cats and ferrets will no longer be valid from  January , prompting a huge surge in red tape. Current requirements say your pet should be vaccinated and microchipped three weeks before the first visit. But for any holidays after December , you must visit a vet at least four months before you travel. First you must get the animal vaccinated against rabies. Then you must wait at least  days before having a blood sample taken. Another three months after that , you can travel. The vet must give you a copy of the test results and an animal health certicate . But you need to time this move carefully, because once your vet produces the certicate, it’s only valid for  days to take your pet into the EU. This process may become easierthe UK joins the EU’s register of “listed” countries, but that’s not guaranteed yet.Do I need to change my travel insurance Quite possibly. Currently UK travellers to the EU don’t need private health insurance, because they’re covered by European Health Insurance Cards . But EHICs will no longer guarantee you free cover in EU nations from January . The government has still not published full details of health arrangements between dferent countries in the EU. But tourists are being urged to buy “comprehensive” travel insurance that covers “all needs” to fill any gaps.Will there be data roaming charges  Quite possibly. Mobile phone users currently get free data roaming across the whole of the EU. But after January , Brits will no longer get this privilege and phone firms will be free to hit you with roaming charges. You must check with your phone provider to seeyou will be affected. If you are hit with roaming charges, you can rack up a bill of £ before you are prompted and askedyou want to spend more.What will the duty-free rules be Duty-free shopping willafter January  for Brits who are going to the continent. This means people can buy duty-free goods in British ports, airports and international rail stations before leaving for the EU. It also means people can bring in goods they’ve bought duty-free in EU airports back to the UK. However, there will be a limit on how much booze or tobacco Brits can bring home from the EU. A ‘booze cruise’ will be able to bring  litres of beer, and  litres of still wine, and  litres of spirits or  litres of sparkling or fortied wine. You can also bring back either  cigarettes, or  cigarillos, or  cigars, or g tobacco - or a combination of the above.Can I drive my car in the EU Yes, but there will be more red tape. Currently a UK driving licence is the only thing visitors need to get behind the wheel on the continent. But from January  many countries will require you to get an International Driving Permit, which costs £. at the Post Office. The number issued each year is expected to soar from , to million. It’s not yet clear which type of IDP you’ll need for which countries. The government is yet to confirm. Meanwhile, you will also be forced to apply for a aposgreen cardapos to prove you have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies, though firms may increase admin fees to deal with red tape. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting.Can I watch Netflix and Amazon Prime on holiday  Subscription services like Netflix and Amazon Prime will no longer be forced by law to let you watch your account in full in the EU.While the exact policy is up to inidual companies, in theory you could lose access to some contentyou’re watching overseas. It is because the UK will no longer be bound by the EU’s “portability regulation” from January .WhatI’ve booked a package holiday  Package holidaymakers could be left with no legal protectionthe firm they booked with goes bust. Currently Brits have insolvency protectionthey book with a package holiday provider thataposs based anywhere in the EU. But after January , that protection will only applythe firms are established in the UK or ”actively targeting the UK market. If you’re unsure, check the firm’s terms and conditions before you book to make sure you’ll be protected. Will I face queues at the border or ports It is possible, especially at the Channel ports like Dover. Businesses will face new red tape from January  , especiallythere is no trade deal between the UK and EU. In preparation, the government is ready to have thousands of lorries queuing down Kent motorways and a network of Brexit lorry parks. All this could cause disruption at the border, and it may not just be limited to freight ports. A confidential document seen by thealso predicted thousands of passengers could have to wait an additional two hours for Eurostar trains.Can I still use my credit or debit card abroad Check with your issuer, but essentially, yes. However, you may be charged more for using credit or debit cards to pay for things in euros when you buy from companies in the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway. Payments may also take longer.WhatI’m an EU national in the UK EU nationals living in the UK must register for “settled status”they want to stay after January , and millions have already done so. The deadline to apply is  June . To get settled status, you must have been living in the UK for at least five years continuously, without a break of more than six months. If you have not been in the UK for this long, you can get ‘pre-settled status’. You will then have to make a second application when you reach the five-year mark to upgrade it to settled status. There is no fee to apply for the scheme after the government agreed to demands to scrap it.WhatI’m an UK national in the EU You may need to apply for residency status in the country you’re living in before June . You may also need to buy health insurance or register for healthcare for the country you are living in. And you may need to exchange your drivers’ licence for a local one - among other things. title: im spending christmas total silence
story: NewsIm spending my Christmas in total silence with a complete strangerSherylin Thompson wont be spending Christmas Day with her family opening presents this year - instead shell be going away to spend it on a silence retreatmirrorShareCommentsBySherylin Thompson:,  DEC NewsSherylin has now been on  silent retreats - and this year will be her sixth at Christmas" %, rgba, rgba, url"Join the Secret Elves to discover the best shopping deals and things to do this ChristmasSpread the Christmas cheer!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis year I’m spending Christmas in silence. Complete silence. There’ll be no cards, no presents, no crackers or trimmings – not even a glass of fizz. In fact, on Christmas Day, itself, I’ll be waking up next to a stranger. As crazy as it may sound, I can’t wait.I had no idea what meditation was until I went to Thailand in . I’d separated from my husband after four years of marriage and went away to do some soul-searching.One day I went on a trip with a group of people to a beautul temple and we were askedwe would like to do meditation. I was the only volunteer.  The monk got me to sit in the lotus position, which was terribly painful, then asked me to close my eyes and to see a flame in front of me and focus on my breath.All I could think about was how sore my knees were and what I’d be having for dinner. I couldn’t wait for it to end. It went on for two hours, but when I walked out afterwards, I felt amazing. My senses were heightened, I felt so aware and alert and relaxed. It was incredible. I was training in psychology and interested in how the mind worked so, back in London, I found a meditation class and started going once a week. I bought meditation CDs and books and even a cushion so I could practise at home. I got so into it, my mother became concerned. She thought I was conversing with spirits, trying to become a medium or something.My parents are strong churchgoers and had no idea about meditation. They thought it could be dangerous and affect my mind. But the more I practised, the more I could feel myself benefiting. It helped me understand myself and my relationships better, it helped me come to terms with my orce.I can be quite self-critical and it helped me to be less harsh on myself and learn to manage those critical thoughts better. I felt calmer. I wanted to immerse myself in it more fully so, that year, I went on a Christmas retreat.I’d spent the previous Christmas partying with friends, so spending it in silence couldn’t be more dferent. I didn’t tell my parents or my friends or work colleagues. I thought they’d think I’d become some kind of crazy hippy and it was all a bit weird. I was almost ashamed of it. The retreat was at a Quaker school in Oxfordshire and fairly basic. I was told to bring comfy clothes and slippers. The dormitories were in outbuildings and quite cold. I was relieved to get a room to myself.  But the biggest challenge was the silence. It was a beginner’s retreat for  days so they introduced it gradually – a couple of hours a day, then half a day, then a full day. I still found it dficult. The fact it was Christmas made it harder.I was glad I’d taken a book and spent most of the time reading, then I found out you’re not supposed to read, you’re supposed to avoid all communication, including reading, eye contact and smiling. It’s all about “stilling the mind”. I was tempted to send a text, but I tried to respect the silence because you don’t have that in ordinary le – it’s rare. Everyone was allocated a task – chopping vegetables or washing up, sometimes cleaning the toilet. In between meditation , we got on with our tasks. Of course there is no speaking, so the tasks were listed for us to see on a notice board.Christmas Day was just like any other day. There were no decorations, carols or trimmings. We had a nut roast for dinner and sat in silence.I found it strange at first. It felt rude to be sitting down with no one talking – eating is such a social thing.But after a couple of days, my mind began to slow down and settle and I actually found it quite nice. It took the pressure off making conversation and I could enjoy the food more.It was the same routine every day – we got woken by the bell at am, we did meditation before breakfast, then got on with our tasks. Then, after sitting or walking meditation in the grounds, it was time for lunch. The food was vegetarian or vegan – simple, but good. Always freshly prepared and it smelled lovely. There was no alcohol. I enjoy a glass of wine, but I didn’t miss it.Katy Perry, Jenner Aniston, Madonna and Angelina Jolie have all spoken about the benefits of meditation. Silent retreats were among the top wellness trends for  and often attract people aged  to . Retreats offer the chance to rest, reflect and reconnect with nature, do yoga, swim, walk or simply nap. Prices in the UK y from £ for a weekend to between £ and £ for  days.

title: couple who 14 miscarriages welcome
story: NewsCouple who had  miscarriages welcome miracle baby after winning IVF on FacebookJo Scollen, , and her husband Jason, , from Wimbledon, south-west London, suffered  miscarriages and at one point they "might as well give up" on their dream of having a babymirrorShareCommentsByFiona Jackson:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsParents Jason and Jo Scollen with their miracle baby Jessica Rose " %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A couple finally welcomed their miracle baby after suffering  miscarriages and then winning IVF in a competition on Facebook. Jo Scollen, , and her husband Jason, , suffered a baby loss nearly every year since they started trying for a child in , and at one point doctors even told them they might as well give up. Jo had no trouble conceiving, but the pregnancy never lasted longer than  weeks and initially doctors couldnapost work out why. They tried IVF, but it didnapost work, and with funds running out Jo had all but given up hope when she entered a competition for a free round of fertility treatment in Cyprus out of desperation. Against all the odds they won and the procedure worked, and the couple, from Wimbledon, south-west London, welcomed baby Jessica Rose into the family last year. Jo said: It was unbelievable. I was at the stage where I was on my knees and about to give up. “After having that many disappointments, you’re dicing with emotional death the whole way through the process. “We had literally run out of funds at that point- both financially and emotionally- and it came entirely out of the blue. “It was a miraculous bolt of positivity. Jessica has been a dream. You’ve never known a more determined baby, and you can tell where she gets it from.  “I don’t think there has ever been a baby that’s more wanted than her. “With Covid everything has been locked down so we’ve not been able to do many of those things I’ve waited  years to do, like seeing family or just going shopping, which is heartbreaking. “But she is here, full of le, and I am so grateful. Jo and Jason, both home renovators, met in a pub in Wimbledon in . They started dating and quickly moved in together, then began trying for a baby after just a year. “Neither of us had a typical lestyle growing up and it was our common bond that we wanted to have a family- and lots of animals. she said. Jo became pregnant for the first time in , and suffered her first loss the same year, when she was around seven weeks along. She said: That was horrendous - all our hopes for the future were there and then our world fell apart. I had to stay in hospital for a week after that. “But it is in both of our natures to not give up easily, we are survivors in our makeup, so we just tried to dust ourselves off and try again.  She said she was unable to get any answers from UK doctors about why she kept having miscarriages. Because she had no problem falling pregnant, she did not consider IVF at the time. In need of a break and a change, they sold everything and moved to Granada, Spain in . She said: It wasn’t working over the years and it was getting harder to deal with in the midst of London. There was so much around that we couldn’t get our heads together.  We came here to reduce stress and simply our le, thinking maybe that would help. She said she was able to get more tests in Spain to look into why she was having miscarriages. Medics discovered she had three types of blood clotting disorders and additional immune factors like chronic fatigue syndromethat could be affecting her pregnancies. Jo said they told her it would be so hard to remain pregnant she might as well give up, she said. She suffered  miscarriages in total before she turned to reproductive assistance in Spain in  which cost about £,. This, alongside all the costs involved in seeing specialists and undergoing tests, was racking up quite a bill for the couple.  A specialist miscarriage doctor from Epsom, Surrey, advised Jo that a precise timing of the medications involved in the procedure could give her a glimmer of hope. She said: We decided it was something that we hadnapost tried before and we should give it a go. Again she fell pregnant as a result, but had her th miscarriage in . “I was on the verge of giving up - each pregnancy and miscarriage was dferent and traumatic in a dferent way, she said. “A lot of clinics said IVF wouldn’t work because I wasn’t having any trouble getting pregnant, which is what the treatment is intended to help with, I just couldn’t hold on to the baby. “There were some clinics that dealt specically with recurrent miscarriages, but we still weren’t successful there.”  Sheaposd almost given up hope when she came across a competition by magazine ivfbabble on Facebook, with a prize of a free cycle of IVF, in November .The competition was to commemorate  years since the birth of the first IVF baby, Louisa Brown. “I just clicked in a desperate moment and then completely forgot about it, said Jo. “We proceeded to have our th loss and I thought there was no point carrying on, but then I got the email through saying I’d won. “I had to ring them up and check that it wasn’t an international scam. “When my husband and I realised it was true, he said ‘I’ve only ever won a bag of crisps’.” Jo and Jason were one of ten winners and believe their baby could have been the first one born from the prize procedure.  Their procedure was scheduled in the Dunya clinic in Cyprus, and the couple travelled for  hours from their home in Spain in November . “Whilst the IVF cycle was free, we had to fund our travel there which wasn’t easy as we live in the middle of nowhere and we ended up having to go via Istanbul, she said. “There were many flight delays, and we had to arrange for care for our many animals, but with IVF everything has a very strict timeline so we had to leave right away. “The benefit of IVF for me was that the medication was timed specically for my cycle and helped with some of the roadblocks. An error led to the failure of the first cycle of IVF before the implantation stage. “We were devastated as this was supposed to be our miracle moment, she said. The clinic offered them a second cycle, so the couple ed to Cyprus in February . Four weeks later, Jo and Jason went to Cartagena to find out the positive result via a blood test.  She said: I had to have IV intralipids immediately after the test came back positive and continued to have those throughout the pregnancy. I also had strong steroid injections and daily heparin injections- the approach was a lot more aggressive and wasnapost very nice, My fertility coach, who dealt with complicated pregnancies, meditation and hypnosis helped me find my centre and made me more mentally prepared than ever before, Even with the positive result, Jo was never complacent. “Our hearts were in our mouths the entire time, she said. We kept thinking that this was the miracle for us and everything must be falling into place. “Then it all started to happen, step-by-step. “With every scan and every week I was petried. Jason had me wrapped in bubble wrap - but I was treated as high-risk and I had appointments or scans more-or-less every fortnight.  “There was never a moment when we thought ‘Thank goodness for that it’s all going to be OK’. “Throughout the whole pregnancy, right up to delivery, we held our breath. She went into labour but  hours after her waters broke her baby still hadnapost arrived, so she had an emergency c-section on October . Jessica Rose, now  months old, was born healthy, weighing .lb. She said: In the end I had a caesarean and she was delivered in  minutes, but both my husband and my translator had to wait outside so I didn’t have much idea what was going on. “I was quickly whisked into recovery and had to stay in hospital for four or five days, but I just couldn’t wait to get back home. “Even when she was born I had to keep checking she was really there - I still can’t believe it happened for us. I still check now, but every week she becomes more real. “People see it as a selfish thing to continue after so many failures and this is why it’s a dficult subject - people just don’t understand why I would do it.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA brave dad has told of how a rampaging murderer who had just brutally killed his ex-girlfriend stabbed at his head, and left his ear hanging off. Gerard Bristow told the Liverpool Echo that crazed ex-cage fighter Andrew Wadsworth chased him down the street in an attempt to kill him. Wadsworth aposmade a beelineapos for him just moments after he stabbed beautician Melissa Belshaw to death in her upstairs bedroom. Alarming CCTV footage released earlier this week revealed how the cocaine-addled murderer pursued him along the street, viciously swiping at him with the long carving blade as he desperately backed away. Dressed in flip flops and shorts, he was ill-prepared for such a terrying and le-threatening confrontation. The dad described how he and another heroic passerby were bravely primed to go inside the Upholland Road house in Billinge after hearing terrible screams from inside, where the mum-of-one had just been fatally attacked. Van driver Kevin Moores bravely smashed into the locked house with a hammer. But within seconds, violent criminal Wadsworth came outside and set upon Mr Bristow, aiming savage blows at him with the kne. Many were focused at the neighbouraposs head, thankfully missing their target, but managing to slice the -year-oldaposs ear instead.  Mr Bristow said: I heard her [Melissaaposs teenage daughter] screaming saying aposmy mumaposs been killed.apos Me and this lad [Kevin Moores] were stood there, wondering what do we do next. He said, aposdo you wanna go in the house  I said, aposyeah,apos and before we knew it, there was Andrew Wadsworth trying to climb out of the smashed porch window. Mr Bristow said: We were stood behind the car.  But because I was asking the questions, aposis she okay in there apos several times, he said aposyeah, sheaposs fine... Iaposm just after the Scouser next doorapos. And within seconds he made a beeline for me, and I actually think it was because I was the one asking all the questions. He was suddenly on top of me, he pulled a kne out of his trousers, down to his left hand and side, and thataposs when he started coming at me with the kne. I believe he got my ear, going for my head obviously, but he managed to take part of my ear off, it was hanging on. Unfortunately I had flip flops on at the time, I wasnapost really prepared for this. Mr Moores raced over and kicked Wadsworth as he was on top of Mr Bristow as he pinned him down, which allowed the -year-old to stagger away. Who would have thought that sewage could provide answers to a medical problem  It turns out sewage could be a useful tool not only in the diagnosis of Covid- but also in providing data on locating virus hotspots. A report in the BMJ by medical writer Zosia Kmietowicz explains that sewage is known to be a great way to spot the ious kinds of infections and dferent strains of bacteria within communities. This applies to viruses too and in particular coronavirus, says Davey Jones, professor of soil and environmental science at Bangor University. Scientists have been collecting wastewater to check for RNA from SARS-CoV- in sewage since the start of the pandemic. Jones believes sewage reflects the public’s health. If you know how to examine it, it reveals secrets. It’s been used to track antimicrobial resistance in the community, drug use and microplastics, as well as other viruses such as norovirus and hepatitis. Sewage can act as an early warning system. By taking samples of wastewater in North Wales, Jones believes sewage helped spot the surge in cases among students in September, before they were tested. This knowledge put scientists on the front foot to control the virus. What’s more, further analysis will help to determinethe current lockdown measures are working. The study, led by i media research at Goldsmiths University of London, on behalf of plant powered snack brand, ZENB Veggie Bites, found water was the most effective at increasing positive emotions, such as happiness and inspiration. In total,  per cent reported that they felt an increase in happiness and  per cent felt inspired after watching scenes of water environments. Seas, lakes and rivers were associated with the highest percentage changeacross participants’ perceived abilities to perform cognitive tasks after being immersed in the environment. Meanwhile, the research highlighted how woodlands can have the most restorative effects on people’s thoughts. story: NewsPrimary school pupil praised for hilarious homework answer after spotting glaring errorA young girl has left people impressed with her no-nonsense answer to a homework question containing an error after a photo of her work was shared on RedditmirrorShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsAudience Writer:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe student spotted a flaw in the teachers question" %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
